newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks soar to new record on rates hope.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks soar to new record on rates hope.

text.p: Mexican stocks soared to notch up their third record close in as many sessions on Tuesday.
Traders said forecast falls in primary rates, expected favorable 1996 earnings reports and steady gains on Wall Street coaxed buyers into the market.
Final closing figures showed the leading IPC share index had ended up 48.92 points, or 1.26 percent, at a record of 3,938.69.
Trading volume was brisk at 103.8 million shares.
"The market well withstood intraday profit-taking, foreigners are still stepping in and we expect (primary) rates to fall," a desk trader said.

A Reuters survey of eight money market traders in Mexico City showed they expected the Banco de Mexico, the country's central bank, to assign bellwether 28-day Cetes at 18.86 percent at its weekly auction of government securities.
This would be a fall of 60 basis points since last week's auction and a rate unseen since an abrupt devaluation of the peso sent Mexican financial markets into a tailspin in December 1994.
Both Kof and Ahmsa ended among the leading percentage gainers.

"Kof began the charge today, which posted an excellect report. Other stocks like GCC and Autrey also look like coming good," said Jaime Hernandez, an equity analyst at the Interacciones brokerage. Analysts also said
that gains on Wall Street propped up the bourse.
"The Dow Jones helped us, albeit relatively, as lack of volatility on Wall Street is a benfit," said Rodolfo Campuzano, an analyst at the Invex brokerage.
Fernandez noted that the bourse now had limited scope for further gains in the near future.

"Technically, the bourse is showing signs of fatigue and overbuying. The market now offers the possibility to divest and take good profits, considering March and April are historically slow months," he said.
"Our June target for the IPC is still 4,100 points," he added.
On the broad market, 122 stocks changed hands, with gainers heavily outnumbering decliners, by 70 to 28.
Traders said soft drinks bottlers Ggemex CPO shares were notable gainers, up 94 centavos to 13.70 pesos on favorable earnings by Kof.
Kof's holding company Femsa B shares also gained strongly, ending up 1.90 pesos at 32.95 pesos.
Traders said the bottlers may also have gained on speculation that soft drinks prices were about to rise.
Financially-troubled autoparts maket Iasasa headed the decliners' list, off three centavos to 50 centavos, followed by retail stock, which fell 38 centavos at 6.52 pesos.
((--Karina Balderas, Mexico City newsroom +525 728-7907))
